group.intro: Duplicate beans have been detected. The mechanism will be unable to determine which class an injected reference refers to
group.background: If there are multiple implementations of some interface or base class then use the bean's "name" property to distinguish them and then include that name in the bean reference whose value is to be injected
group.template: attempt to add duplicate bean: {Interface1} {BeanName}, attempting to add ${NewBean}, when ${ExistingBean} is already included.

group.intro: A class has been marked as a bean (with the "Bean" attribute) which is not capable of being a bean. The only types that can be beans are concrete non-static classes.
group.background: Typically this problem occurs with abstract and static classes. Note that although the bean reference where the injection takes place may be specified as a base class or interface, the "Bean" attribute should be applied only to the concrete implementation, not to a parent or interface

group.intro: An attempt has been made to set the value of an auto property. The container cannot do this.
group.background: The container cannot set the value of an auto property as the operation is not supported by reflection.

group.intro: A class or struct without a no-arg constructor has been encountered. All types in the object tree must have no-arg constructors
group.background: The container needs to be able to construct the objects in the tree by reflection .For this it needs a non-static constructor which takes no arguments. Alternatively a constructor annotated with the [Constructor] attribute can be specified together with all of its parameters annotated as [BeanReference]

group.intro: A reference to a missing bean has been encountered
group.background: The most likely cause of this issue is that you forgot to mark a bean with [Bean] or omitted its name for the [BeanReference] or there are duplicate beans or that the bean referred to was not a concrete class or struct. (In the case of duplicates the details should be listed in the relevant diagnostics above). Alternatively you may have attempted to mark as injectable a non-bean class such as a primitive, dynamic, tuple, array or 3rd party library class. This, of course, amounts to much the same thing. You may be attempting the bean through an interface that it does not implement.
group.template: Missing bean referred to at: ({MemberType}({MemberBeanName}) {MemberName}) declared by {Bean}

group.intro: The bean specified as the root of the tree cannot be found
group.background: The most likely cause of this issue is that you forgot to mark a bean with [Bean] or there are duplicate beans or that the bean referred to was not a concrete class or struct. (In the case of duplicates the details should be listed in the relevant diagnostics above). Alternatively you may have attempted to access a non-bean class such as a primitive, dynamic, tuple, array or 3rd party library class. This, of course, amounts to much the same thing. You may be attempting the bean through an interface that it does not implement.

group.intro: The root of the class tree was not marked as [Bean] or the bean was invalid - see diagnostics above
group.background: The most likely cause of this issue is that the type passed to PDependencyInjector.CreateAndInjectDependencies was not marked as a bean. [Bean] or the concrete class derived from the type was not marked as a bean. Alternatively the bean may have been found to be invalid - see above.
group.template: Missing root bean referred to as: ({BeanType}({BeanName}))

group.intro: No factory has been found for member(s) marked with a factory bean
group.background: Factory beans must be marked as beans [Bean]. They must be in an assembly passed to PDependencyInjector.SetAssemblies().

group.intro: A factory has been found but it does not implement the required IFactory interface
group.background: Factory beans must be marked as beans [Bean]. They must also implement IFactory.

group.intro: The type assigned to a member by a factory was incompatible
group.background: The type of the object returned by the Execute() method of a factory must be compatible with the type of the member to which it is being assigned
group.template: The type returne from {Factory} for {DeclaringBean}.{Member} {ExpectedType} was expected.Excepton: {Exception}

group.intro: An error occurred when creating a bean using bean factory
group.background: An exception was thrown during the Execute() method of a bean factory
group.template: The exception thrown by {Factory} for {DeclaringBean}.{Member} was {Exception}

group.intro: A cyclical dependency was found in the object tree. This is not supported
group.background: A cyclical dependency occurs when a class constructor includes a parameter whose own constructor includes a parameter of the original class. Add in intermediate ancestors to make this interesting a parent bean or
group.template: The declaring bean {DeclaringBean} has cyclical dependency related to {ConstructorParam}

group.intro: More than one suitable constructor is available for injection
group.background: The container needs an exact specification of the constructor to be run. Where there are two candidate constructors then each should be given a differnt "Name" and the "ConstructorName" parameter of the [BeanReference] should be used in the reference to the bean to indicate which constructor should be used.
group.template: The declaring bean {Bean} has more than one applicable constructor

group.intro: A constructor has been found marked as [Constructor] but one or more of whose parameters are not marked as [BeanReference]
group.background: In order to inject values into a class (bean) via the constructor its constructor must be marked with the [Constructor] attribute and all that constructor's parameters must be marked as [BeanReference]. If a parameter to be injected is not a bean then a factory bean can be used to provide the value and the constructor should be marked [BeanReference(Factory=typeof(SomeFactoryClass)]
group.template: The declaring bean {Bean}'s constructor has unmarked parameters

group.intro: A constructor has been found not marked as [Constructor] but one or more of whose parameters is marked as [BeanReference]
group.background: In order to inject values into a class (bean) via the constructor its constructor must be marked with the [Constructor] attribute and all that constructor's parameters must be marked as [BeanReference].
group.template: One or more of the declaring bean {Bean}'s constructors is not marked as [Constructor] but has marked parameters

group.intro: Two beans has been found that are mutually dependent using constructor injection. This is not supported
group.background: If a reference to Bean A is injected into Bean B's constructor and a reference to Bean B is injected into Bean A's constructor then there is no way to construct both beans.

group.intro: A bean reference exists in a context where a bean cannot be injected
group.background: All members for which beans can be injected must exist within classes validly marked as [bean]s.

group.intro: A injectable constructor exists in a context where a bean cannot be injected
group.background: All constructors for which beans can be injected must exist within classes validly marked as [bean]s.

group.intro: A class exists which implements the IFactory interface but which is not marked as a [Bean]
group.background: Factories must implement IFactory and be marked with the [Bean] attribute.
group.template: {Type} implements IFactory but is not a bean

group.intro: A value is being injected into a member that has already been initialized
group.background: Values are injected after a bean has been instantiated, constructor has executed and member initialisations have occurred. Any preceding initialisation will be obliterated by the injection
group.template: The member, {Member}, of {DeclaringType} was already initialized with {ExistingValue}. The value, {ExistingValue}, has been overwritten

group.intro: An embedded struct bean exists which will never be instantiated
group.background: Embedded structs must be marked as [BeanReference] in order for their bean reference members to be injected

group.intro: List of Profiles in use by the container
group.background: The active profiles will determine which types are included in the type map and are available for injection

group.intro: List of Assemblies in use by the container
group.background: The active assemblies will determine which types are included in the type map and are available for injection

group.intro: List of Types available for injection together with their mapping
group.background:
The mapping shows what implementation* (concrete class) will be injected for a reference with the given Type (interface, base class, or concrete class). Only types in this list are available for injection.
* Note that in the case of references containing factories it is the factory implementation rather than the actual derived class that is reported.

group.intro: List of objects injected by the container into member variables
List of objects injected by the container into the constructor
group.template: {ParameterImplementation} has been injected into the constructor of {DeclaringType}

group.intro: Attempt to call CreateAndInjectDependencies() from factory without passing down the creation context
group.background: In the Execute() method of a factory object the dependency injector is being used to create some object and inject its dependencies. This pattern requires that the "parent's" CreationContext is passed down to ensure that no cycclical dependencies are introduced unbeknownst to the injector. The parent's creationContext can be found in the BeanFactoryArgs object passed in as a parameter.
